full_statement: Baptism is ordinarily an instrument through which God grants regeneration (new birth), not merely a symbolic representation.
definition_variants: Regeneration as the beginning of new spiritual life (new birth).
Regeneration as covenantal incorporation + new status (adoption/identity).
Regeneration as a grace ordinarily given through baptism, with exceptions (e.g., desire, martyrdom).

full_statement: Baptism is ordinarily connected with the remission of sins (including, in some traditions, original sin).
definition_variants: Remission of sins as real cleansing/forgiveness granted by God.
Remission of sins as promised forgiveness received in faith through a sign.
Remission of sins as tied to baptism but not to the moment of administration.

full_statement: Baptism is ordinarily connected with incorporation into Christ and visible membership in the Church.
definition_variants: Incorporation as visible entry into the covenant community.
Incorporation as spiritual union with Christ (variously related to faith, election, and sacramental theology).

full_statement: Baptism’s promised grace is related to faith and may not be tied to the exact moment of administration (depending on tradition).
definition_variants: Faith as the means by which baptism’s promise is received.
Grace conferred in God’s appointed time, not mechanically at administration.

full_statement: Baptism is not a mechanical guarantee that works automatically apart from God’s Word/promise, proper reception, or the broader economy of grace.
definition_variants: Anti-‘opus operatum’ framing: the rite is not a self-acting machine.
Distinguish objective institution (valid baptism) from subjective benefit (received rightly / in faith / appointed time).

short_label: The Son is co-eternal with the Father
full_statement: The Son (Logos) is not a creature but eternally begotten of the Father, sharing the same divine essence.
definition_variants: Eternally begotten: the Son has no beginning in time.
Homoousios: the Son is 'of one substance' with the Father.
Against Arianism: the Son is not the first-created being.

short_label: The Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father (and the Son)
full_statement: The Holy Spirit eternally proceeds from the Father (and, in Western traditions, also from the Son — the Filioque).
definition_variants: Eastern: proceeds from the Father alone (through the Son in economy).
Western (Filioque): proceeds from the Father and the Son as from one principle.
Joint procession vs. monarchy of the Father.

short_label: Three distinct persons, one divine essence
full_statement: God is one divine essence (ousia) subsisting in three distinct persons (hypostases): Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.
definition_variants: One 'what' (essence/nature), three 'whos' (persons/hypostases).
Neither modalism (one person in three modes) nor tritheism (three gods).
Each person is fully God; the persons are distinct but inseparable.

full_statement: The 'economic' Trinity (how God acts in salvation history) reflects but does not exhaust the 'immanent' Trinity (God's eternal inner life).
definition_variants: Economic roles (Father sends, Son is sent) do not imply ontological inferiority.
The missions reveal the processions but the persons remain co-equal.
Subordinationism rejected: functional order does not mean lesser divinity.

short_label: Christ is truly present in the Eucharist
full_statement: In the Eucharist, Christ is truly present — not merely symbolized or remembered — though traditions differ on the mode of presence.
definition_variants: Substantial presence: Christ's body and blood are really present under the forms of bread and wine.
Sacramental union: Christ's body and blood are present 'in, with, and under' the elements.
Spiritual presence: Christ is present to faith through the Holy Spirit.

short_label: The elements become Christ's body and blood
full_statement: The bread and wine are transformed (or joined) to become or convey Christ's body and blood, though the nature of this change is debated.
definition_variants: Transubstantiation: the substance changes while accidents remain.
Sacramental union: the elements remain bread/wine while also conveying Christ's body/blood.
Symbolic view: the elements represent but do not become the body and blood.

short_label: The Eucharist is a sacrifice / memorial
full_statement: The Eucharist is understood as a sacrifice, a memorial, or both — traditions differ on whether it re-presents Christ's sacrifice or commemorates it.
definition_variants: Propitiatory sacrifice: the Mass makes present Christ's once-for-all sacrifice.
Sacrifice of thanksgiving: the Eucharist is an offering of praise and self-dedication.
Memorial (Zwinglian): the Lord's Supper is a remembrance, not a sacrifice.

full_statement: Receiving the Eucharist worthily requires proper disposition — faith, repentance, or sacramental preparation — with unworthy reception bringing judgment.
definition_variants: Faith as the means of receiving Christ's benefits in the sacrament.
Sacramental preparation (confession, fasting) as prerequisites.
Judgment on those who eat and drink 'without discerning the body' (1 Cor 11:29).
